cpystal.analysis package

Submodules

cpystal.analysis.analysis module

cpystal.analysis is a module for theoretical calculations and making some useful data files for numerical analysis.

Functions:
brillouin

-Brillouin function B_J(x).

paramagnetization_curie

-Magnetization from Curie paramagnetism.

fit_paramagnetism

-Fitting magnetic field dependence of magnetic moment to theoretical paramagnetism.

demagnetizing_factor_ellipsoid

-Calculating demagnetizing factor of ellipsoid 2a x 2b x 2c.

demagnetizing_factor_rectangular_prism

-Calculating demagnetizing factor of rectangular prism axbxc.

cpystal.analysis.analysis.brillouin(x: float, J: float) → float[source]

Brillouin function B_J(x).

Parameters:

  • x (float) – Real parameter.

  • J (float) – Integer of half integer (corresponds to total momentum quantum number).

Returns:

B_J(x).

Return type:

(float)

cpystal.analysis.analysis.demagnetizing_factor_ellipsoid(a: float, b: float, c: float) → tuple[float, float, float][source]

Calculating demagnetizing factor of ellipsoid 2a x 2b x 2c.

Parameters:

  • a (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

  • b (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

  • c (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

Returns:

Demagnetizing factor Nx, Ny, Nz.

Return type:

(tuple[float])

cpystal.analysis.analysis.demagnetizing_factor_rectangular_prism(a: float, b: float, c: float) → float[source]

Calculating demagnetizing factor of rectangular prism axbxc.

Thesis:

A. Aharoni et al., Journal of Applied Physics 83, 3432 (1998). (See also: http://www.magpar.net/static/magpar/doc/html/demagcalc.html)

Parameters:

  • a (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

  • b (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

  • c (float) – Length of an edge (arb. unit).

Returns:

Demagnetizing factor.

Return type:

(float)

cpystal.analysis.analysis.fit_paramagnetism(material: Crystal, H: list[float], moment: list[float], T: float) → tuple[float, float][source]

Fitting magnetic field dependence of magnetic moment to theoretical paramagnetism.

Note

M = n g J B_J(g muB J H/kB T) [muB/f.u.], where

n = number of magnetic atom per formula unit, g = g factor, J = total angular momentum quantum number, B_J = Brillouin function, kB = Boltzmann constant, H = magnetic field, T = temperature.

Parameters:

  • material (Crystal) – Crystal instance.

  • H (list[float]) – Magnetic field (Oe).

  • moment (list[float]) – Magnetic moment (emu).

Returns:

g and J.

Return type:

(tuple[float, float])

cpystal.analysis.analysis.main() → None[source]
cpystal.analysis.analysis.paramagnetization_curie(H: float, T: float, g: float, J: float, n: int) → float[source]

Magnetization from Curie paramagnetism.

Note

M = n g J B_J(g muB J H/kB T) [muB/f.u.], where

n = number of magnetic atom per formula unit, g = g factor, J = total angular momentum quantum number, B_J = Brillouin function, kB = Boltzmann constant (J/K), H = magnetic field (Oe), T = temperature (K).

Parameters:

  • H (float) – Magnetic field (Oe).

  • T (float) – Temperature (K).

  • g (float) – g-factor.

  • J (float) – Total angular momentum quantum number.

  • n (float) – Number of magnetic atom per formula unit (1/f.u.).

Returns:

Magnetization from Curie paramagnetism (muB/f.u.).

Return type:

(float)

cpystal.analysis.spacegroup module

cpystal.analysis.spacegroup is a module for analyzing space group of crystal.

crystal_direction(xyz: npt.NDArray) → tuple[int, int, int][source]
crystal_direction_str(xyz: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]) → str[source]
direction_parser(direction: str) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]

parse direction string.

Parameters:

direction (str) – String represented a direction.

Note

direction must follow some rules as below:

  1. “a”, “b”, “c”, “astar”, “bstar”, “cstar” are allowed.

  2. Indices (h, k, l) and (h^*, k^*, l^*) are allowed.

Examples

examples of direction

astar // a* “1-10” // a - b “-1*1*-2” // -a* + b* - 2c

Returns:

Unit vector of the direction.

Return type:

npt.NDArray

Generate atoms by symmetry operations from inequivalent atoms.

Parameters:

  • atoms_data (list[tuple[Atom, int]]) – List of (Atom, multiplicity).

  • is_equate_equivalent_atoms (bool) – If True, equivalent atoms are equated even if the positions of the atoms are different by primitive translation vectors.

Returns:

Atoms.

class cpystal.analysis.spacegroup.PhysicalPropertyTensorAnalyzer(point_group_name: str)[source]

Bases: object

Analyze non-zero elements of physical property tensors based on the symmetry of crystallographic point group.

There is software on the browser that performs similar or better than this class. ‘MTENSOR”: https://www.cryst.ehu.es/cgi-bin/cryst/programs/mtensor.pl If you want to double-check the result of this class, use ‘MTENSOR’.

Note

All symmetry operations of crystallographic point groups can be represented as a 3×3 matrix on a simple rational extension field: ‘M_{3×3}(Q(√3))’ in an appropriate orthorhombic basis. Therefore, it is possible to determine which elements are equivalent or zero by straightforward exact calculation.

point_group_name

Target point group name written in International notation.

Type:

str

unitary_matrices

list of the symmetry operations of the crystallographic point group represented as a matrix in an appropriate orthorhombic basis.

Type:

list[MatrixREF]

C1 = [[1, 0, 0],  [0, 1, 0],  [0, 0, 1]]
C2_001 = [[-1, 0, 0],  [0, -1, 0],  [0, 0, 1]]
C2_010 = [[-1, 0, 0],  [0, 1, 0],  [0, 0, -1]]
C2_01n1 = [[-1, 0, 0],  [0, 0, -1],  [0, -1, 0]]
C2_100 = [[1, 0, 0],  [0, -1, 0],  [0, 0, -1]]
C2_110 = [[0, 1, 0],  [1, 0, 0],  [0, 0, -1]]
C2_1n10 = [[0, -1, 0],  [-1, 0, 0],  [0, 0, -1]]
C2_n101 = [[0, 0, -1],  [0, -1, 0],  [-1, 0, 0]]
C3_001 = [[-1/2, 1/2√3, 0],  [-1/2√3, -1/2, 0],  [0, 0, 1]]
C3_111 = [[0, 0, 1],  [1, 0, 0],  [0, 1, 0]]
C3_1n1n1 = [[0, 0, -1],  [-1, 0, 0],  [0, 1, 0]]
C3_n11n1 = [[0, 0, 1],  [-1, 0, 0],  [0, -1, 0]]
C3_n1n11 = [[0, 1, 0],  [0, 0, -1],  [-1, 0, 0]]
C4_001 = [[0, -1, 0],  [1, 0, 0],  [0, 0, 1]]
C4_010 = [[0, 0, 1],  [0, 1, 0],  [-1, 0, 0]]
C4_100 = [[1, 0, 0],  [0, 0, -1],  [0, 1, 0]]
centrosymmetric_point_groups: list[str] = ['-1', '2/m', 'mmm', '4/m', '4/mmm', '-3', '-3m', '6/m', '6/mmm', 'm-3', 'm-3m']
chiral_point_groups: list[str] = ['1', '2', '222', '4', '422', '3', '32', '6', '622', '23', '432']
enantiomorphous_point_groups: list[str] = ['1', '2', '222', '4', '422', '3', '32', '6', '622', '23', '432']
get_elements_info(rank: int, axiality: bool, expr: str | None = None) → None[source]

Determine which elements of a tensor are equivalent or zero by straightforward exact calculation based on Neumann’s principle.

Note

All analysis results are output to stdout.

Parameters:

  • rank (int) – Rank of target physical property tensor.

  • axiality (bool) – True if the tensor is an axial tensor.

  • expr (str | None) – String representing a relation between elements that is already known. Some relations shall be separated by comma.

Returns:

Indices(0-indexed) of non-zero elements of the tensor.

Return type:

(list[tuple[int, …]])

Examples

>>> point_group_name = spacegroup_to_pointgroup("Fd-3m") # Pyrochlore
>>> assert point_group_name == "m-3m"
>>> PPTA = PhysicalPropertyTensorAnalyzer(point_group_name)
>>> PPTA.get_elements_info(rank=4, axiality=False, expr="ijkl=ijlk=jikl=klij") # elastic modulus tensor (4-tensor): 4階の弾性率テンソル
>>> PPTA.get_elements_info(rank=3, axiality=False, expr="ijk=ikj") # Optical Parametric Oscillator: 光パラメトリック発振
get_elements_info_from_jahn_symbol(jahn_symbol: str) → None[source]

Determine which elements of a tensor are equivalent or zero by straightforward exact calculation based on Neumann’s principle.

Note

All analysis results are output to stdout.

Parameters:

jahn_symbol (str) – String designating the sort of tensor according to its transformation properties.

Returns:

Indices(0-indexed) of non-zero elements of the tensor.

Return type:

(list[tuple[int, …]])

Examples

>>> point_group_name = spacegroup_to_pointgroup("P-3c1") # Pyrochlore
>>> assert point_group_name == "-3m"
>>> PPTA = PhysicalPropertyTensorAnalyzer(point_group_name)
>>> PPTA.get_elements_info_from_jahn_symbol("ae[V^2]V") # asymmetric part of thermal conductivity propotion to magnetic field linearly
get_info_transport_tensor_under_magnetic_field(magnetic_field_dependence_dimension: int = 0, is_0indexed: bool = False) → None[source]

Determine which elements of a transport tensor are equivalent or zero by straightforward exact calculation based on Neumann’s principle.

Note

All analysis results are output to stdout.

Parameters:

  • magnetic_field_dependence_dimension (int) – Nonnegative integers are allowed. 0: constant components in magnetic field. 1: linear components in magnetic field. 2: quadratic components in magnetic field. 3: cubic components in magnetic field. etc.

  • is_0indexed (bool) – True if the indices of tensor elements in the results are written in 0-indexed form. Defaults to False.

Examples

>>> point_group_name = spacegroup_to_pointgroup("Fd-3m") # Diamond
>>> assert point_group_name == "m-3m"
>>> PPTA = PhysicalPropertyTensorAnalyzer(point_group_name)
>>> PPTA.get_info_transport_tensor_under_magnetic_field(1) # odd terms of a transport tensor
international_to_schoenflies_notation: dict[str, str] = {'-1': 'S2', '-3': 'S6', '-3m': 'D3d', '-4': 'S4', '-42m': 'D2d', '-43m': 'Td', '-4m2': 'D2d', '-6': 'C3h', '-62m': 'D3h', '-6m2': 'D3h', '1': 'C1', '2': 'C2', '2/m': 'C2h', '222': 'D2', '23': 'T', '2mm': 'C2v', '3': 'C3', '32': 'D3', '3m': 'C3v', '4': 'C4', '4/m': 'C4h', '4/m-32/m': 'Oh', '4/mmm': 'D4h', '422': 'D4', '432': 'O', '4mm': 'C4v', '6': 'C6', '6/m': 'C6h', '6/mmm': 'D6h', '622': 'D6', '6mm': 'C6v', 'm': 'S1', 'm-3': 'Th', 'm-3m': 'Oh', 'mm2': 'C2v', 'mmm': 'D2h'}

polar_point_groups: list[str] = ['1', 'm', '2', 'mm2', '4', '4mm', '3', '3m', '6', '6mm']
time_reversal = [[1, 0, 0],  [0, 1, 0],  [0, 0, 1]]
class cpystal.analysis.spacegroup.SpaceGroupSymmetryOperation(crystal_structure: CrystalStructure, expression: str)[source]

Bases: object

generate_atom(atom: Atom) → Atom[source]
operate(pos: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]
operate_spin(spin: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]
classmethod point_group_operation(crystal_structure: CrystalStructure, expression: str) → SpaceGroupSymmetryOperation[source]
Parameters:

  • crystal_structure (CrystalStructure) – Instannce of CrystalStructure.

  • expression (str) –

    Point group symmetry operation written in the following notation. “{op};{crystal_direction}” - op: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, -1, -3, -4, -6, m - crystal_direction: rotation axis or direction perpendicular to the mirror .. rubric:: Examples

    ”-1”: inversion. ‘crystal_direction’ is not necessary. “3;001”: 3-fold rotation along c-axis. “m;100”: mirror operation perpendicular to a-axis.

Returns:

Instannce of SpaceGroupSymmetryOperation.

Return type:

SpaceGroupSymmetryOperation

cpystal.analysis.spacegroup.decompose_jahn_symbol(symbol: str) → tuple[int, str, bool, bool][source]

Extract information of a tensor represented by the given Jahn’s symbol.

Parameters:

  • symbol (str) – Jahn’s symbol.

  • notation] ([Rules of Jahn's symbol) –

  • tensor. (* Symbols in '{}' are asymmetric) –

  • tensor. –

  • tensor. –

  • tensor. –

  • tensor. –

  • operation. (* Symbols in '{}*' are asymmetric tensor by time reversal) –

  • operation. –

Returns:

‘rank’, ‘expression’, ‘axiality’ and ‘time_reversality’ respectively.

rank: Rank of the tensor. expression: Relationship among elements of the tensor represented by formula of indices. axiality: Axiality of the tensor. If it is polar tensor, this value will False. time_reversality: time reversality of the tensor. If it is magnetic tensor, this value will True.

Return type:

(tuple[int, str, bool, bool])

Examples

>>> decompose_jahn_symbol("ae[V^2]V")
>>> (3, 'ijk=jik', True, True)

cpystal.analysis.spacegroup.spacegroup_to_pointgroup(name: str) → str[source]

Convert space group name to point group name.

  1. Capital alphabets and spaces are removed.

  2. Subscripts (represented by “_” with numbers) are removed.

  3. All “1” except a component of monoclinic symbols (“1” or “-1”) are removed.

  4. “a”,”b”,”c”,”d”,”e”, and “n” are converted to “m”

  5. Exception handling.

Parameters:

name (str) – Space group name in International (Hermann-Mauguin) notation.

Returns:

Point group name in International (Hermann-Mauguin) notation converted from the space group name.

Return type:

(str)

Examples

>>> point_group_name = spacegroup_to_pointgroup("Fd-3m") # Diamond
>>> print(point_group_name)
    m-3m

cpystal.analysis.spin_model module

cpystal.analysis.spin_model is a module for analyzing some spin models.

Classes:

SpinOperator MultiSpinSystemOperator

class cpystal.analysis.spin_model.MultiSpinSystemOperator(S: float | list[float], K: int)[source]

Bases: object

Calculation of matrix elements of various spin operators

for a system of K spins whose i-th spin quantum number is S_i.

Note

The bases for the matrix representation are as follows: {|0,S_0>,|0,S_0-1>,…,|0,-S_0>,|1,S_1>,|1,S_1-1>,…}

The shape of returns of each class method is (self.dim, self.dim).

However, only Si_cross_Sj, (3, self.dim, self.dim)
<- Taking the inner product of the DM vector and this,

the DM interaction term will be obtained.

Si_cross_Sj(i: int, j: int) → ndarray[Any, dtype[complex64]][source]

Si x Sj

Note

SixSjy - Siysjx == 1.0j/2 (Si+Sj- - Si-Sj+)

Si_dot_Sj(i: int, j: int) → ndarray[Any, dtype[complex64]][source]

Si dot Sj

(Si+)(Sj-)

SzSz(i: int, j: int) → ndarray[Any, dtype[complex64]][source]

(Siz)(Sjz)

classmethod TDMA(d: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], u: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], l: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], b: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]

excute_1D_Crank_Nicolson(T_init: float, Q: float, kappa: float, c: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]

1D thermal diffusion simulation by Crank-Nicolson method.

Note

The constraint of discretization width (dx,dt) is nothing. The boundary conditions are:

x=0: Neumann condition under steady thermal flux flowing. x=L: Dirichlet condition at the constant temperature T_init.

(1+2θα)T_{n}^(t+1) - θα(T_{n-1}^(t+1) + T_{n+1}^(t+1)) = (1-2(1-θ)α)T_{n}^(t) + (1-θ)α(T_{n-1}^(t) + T_{n+1}^(t))

Parameters:

  • T_init (float) – Initial temperature (K).

  • Q (float) – Heater power (mW).

  • kappa (float) – Thermal conductivity (W/Km).

  • c (float) – Specific heat (J/molK).

Returns:

Temperature distribution T(x,t).

Return type:

npt.NDArray

excute_1D_FTCS(T_init: float, Q: float, kappa: float, c: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]

1D thermal diffusion simulation by Forward Time Center Space explicit method.

Note

The discretization width (dx,dt) must be satisfied the CFL condition as below:

dt/(dx**2) < 1/(2*D),

where D is diffusion coefficient. The boundary conditions are:

x=0: Neumann condition under steady thermal flux flowing. x=L: Dirichlet condition at the constant temperature T_init.

T_{n}^(t+1) = (1-2α)T_{n}^(t) + α(T_{n-1}^(t) + T_{n+1}^(t))

Parameters:

  • T_init (float) – Initial temperature (K).

  • Q (float) – Heater power (mW).

  • kappa (float) – Thermal conductivity (W/Km).

  • c (float) – Specific heat (J/molK).

Returns:

Temperature distribution T(x,t).

Return type:

npt.NDArray

excute_1D_implicit(T_init: float, Q: float, kappa: float, c: float) → ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]][source]

1D thermal diffusion simulation by implicit method with TDMA.

Note

The constraint of discretization width (dx,dt) is nothing. The boundary conditions are:

x=0: Neumann condition under steady thermal flux flowing. x=L: Dirichlet condition at the constant temperature T_init.

(1+2α)T_{n}^(t+1) - α(T_{n-1}^(t+1) + T_{n+1}^(t+1)) = T_{n}^(t)

Parameters:

  • T_init (float) – Initial temperature (K).

  • Q (float) – Heater power (mW).

  • kappa (float) – Thermal conductivity (W/Km).

  • c (float) – Specific heat (J/molK).

Returns:

Temperature distribution T(x,t).

Return type:

npt.NDArray

exp_fit(X: npt.NDArray, Y: npt.NDArray) → tuple[npt.NDArray, tuple[float, float, float]][source]

Exponential fitting.

Parameters:

  • X (npt.NDArray) –

  • Y (npt.NDArray) –

Returns:

Result of fitting and used parameters.

Return type:

tuple[npt.NDArray, tuple[float, float, float]]

snapshot(t: float, T_init: float, Q: float, kappa: float, c: float, mode: str = 'Crank-Nicolson') → None[source]

Visualize temperature distribution at the selected time.

Parameters:

  • t (float) – Time (s).

  • T_init (float) – Initial temperature (K).

  • Q (float) – Heater power (mW).

  • kappa (float) – Thermal conductivity (W/Km).

  • mode (str, optional) – Simulation mode. Defaults to “Crank-Nicolson”.

Raises:

ValueError – mode must be in [“FTCS”, “implicit”, “Crank-Nicolson”, “reuse”]

cpystal.analysis.thermal_conduction.cal_dTx(Q: float, lx: float, w: float, t: float, kxx: float) → float[source]

Calculating temperature difference due to heat current.

Note

dTx = (Q/wt) * (lx/kxx)

Parameters:

  • Q (float) – Heater power (mW).

  • lx (float) – Length between thermocouples (um).

  • w (float) – Width of the sample (um).

  • t (float) – Thickness of the sample (um).

  • kxx (float) – Thermal conductivity (W/Km).

Returns:

dTx (K).

Return type:

(float)

cpystal.analysis.thermal_conduction.main() → None[source]

cpystal.analysis.xrd module

cpystal.analysis.xrd is a module for the analysis of x-ray diffraction by theoretical calculations and making some useful data files for numerical analysis.

Functions:
compare_powder_Xray_experiment_with_calculation

-Compare experimental intensity data of powder X-ray diffraction with theoretical intensity distribution.

compare_powder_Xray_experiment_with_calculation_of_some_materials

-Compare experimental intensity data of powder X-ray diffraction with theoretical intensity distribution of some materials.

make_powder_Xray_diffraction_pattern_in_calculation

-Calculate theoretical intensity distribution of powder X-ray diffraction.

atoms_position_from_p1_file

-Get the position of atoms in unit cell from “.p1” file.

make_struct_file

-Make a “.struct” file from “.cif” file and “.p1” file.

(Crystal)

cpystal.analysis.xrd.compare_powder_Xray_experiment_with_calculation(experimental_data_filename: str, cif_filename: str, material: Crystal | None = None, unbackground: bool = False, issave: bool = False, primitive: bool = False, comparison: bool = True, atomic_form_factor_based_on_ITC: bool = True) → tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Subplot][source]

Compare experimental intensity data of powder X-ray diffraction with theoretical intensity distribution.

Notes

Removing background method should be improved. The argument ‘material’ will be removed in future.

Parameters:

  • experimental_data_filename (str) – Input file name (if necessary, add file path to the head). The suffix of filename must be “.ras”.

  • cif_filename (str) – Input file name (if necessary, add file path to the head). The suffix of filename must be “.cif”.

  • material (Crystal | None) – Crystal instance of the measurement object.

  • unbackground (bool) – If True, remove the background with piecewise linear interpolation. Defaults to False.

  • issave (bool) – If True, save the figure as png. Defaults to False.

  • primitive (bool) – If True, use the primitive unit cell insted of the conventional unit cell. Defaults to False.

  • comparison (bool) – If True, print camparison between experimental peaks and calculational peaks to standard output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

plt.Figure object and plotted plt.Subplot object.

Return type:

(tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Subplot])

cpystal.analysis.xrd.compare_powder_Xray_experiment_with_calculation_of_some_materials(experimental_data_filename: str, cif_filename_list: list[str], unbackground: bool = False, issave: bool = False, primitive: bool = False, comparison: bool = True, atomic_form_factor_based_on_ITC: bool = True) → tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Subplot][source]

Compare experimental intensity data of powder X-ray diffraction with theoretical intensity distribution of some materials.

Notes

Removing background method should be improved.

Parameters:

  • experimental_data_filename (str) – Input file name (if necessary, add file path to the head). The suffix of filename must be “.ras”.

  • cif_filename_list (list[str]) – list of input file name (if necessary, add file path to the head). The suffix of filename must be “.cif”.

  • unbackground (bool) – If True, remove the background with piecewise linear interpolation.

  • primitive (bool) – If True, use the primitive unit cell insted of the conventional unit cell. Defaults to False.

  • comparison (bool) – If True, print camparison between experimental peaks and calculational peaks to standard output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

plt.Figure object and plotted plt.Subplot object.

Return type:

(tuple[plt.Figure, plt.Subplot])

cpystal.analysis.xrd.make_struct_file(cif_filename: str, p1_filename: str) → str[source]

Make a “.struct” file from “.cif” file and “.p1” file.

Atomic coordinates in the “.p1” file must be written as “Fractional coordinates”. The “.struct” file will be saved in the same directory as “.cif” file.

Note

This function will be used for displaying theoretical Laue patterns in “Lauept.exe”.

Parameters:

  • cif_filename (str) – Name of the cif file.

  • p1_filename (str) – Name of the p1 file.

Returns:

The content of saved “.struct” file.

Return type:

(str)
